data.title: Famous Hungarians in History
data.meta_description: List of the most famous Hungarians in history, with famous, important and notable Hungarians hand-picked by our team of editors and ranked by popularity.
data.text:
Famous Hungarians

Home

Famous People

Nationality

Hungarian

1. Harry Houdini

2. Leó Szilárd

3. Franz Joseph I

4. Andrew Grove

5. Elizabeth Báthory

6. Attila

7. Dennis Gabor

8. Peter Carl Goldmark

9. Edward Teller

10. Béla Bartók

11. Joseph Pulitzer

12. Franz Liszt

13. Ernő Rubik

14. Zsa Zsa Gabor

15. Robert Capa

16. George Soros

17. Eugene Ormandy

18. Imre Nagy

19. Viktor Orbán

20. Paul Lukas

21. Franz Lehár

22. Imre Kertész

23. Karl Polanyi

24. John von Neumann

25. Felix Salten

List of Hungarian People

Janus Pannonius, Hungarian poet and translator, born in Čazma, Croatia (d. 1472)

Elizabeth Báthory, Hungarian countess and the world's most prolific female serial killer, born in Nyírbátor, Hungary (d. 1614)

Péter Pázmány, Hungarian cardinal and statesman, born in Nagyvárad, Principality of Transylvania (d. 1637)

Paul Esterhazy, Hungarian prince, composer and patron, born in Eisenstadt (d. 1713)

Johann Sigismund Kusser, Hungarian German composer, born in Pressburg, Kingdom of Hungary (d. 1727)

Francis II Rákóczi, Hungarian nobleman and leader of the Hungarian uprising against the Habsburg, born in Borsi, Royal Hungary (d. 1735)

Andreas Hadik, Austro-Hungarian general (d. 1790)

Eva Marie Veigel [La Violette], Austrian ballet dancer and wife of actor David Garrick, born in Vienna, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1822)

Ferenc Verseghy, Hungarian poet and composer, born in Szolnok, Hungary (d. 1822)

Nikolaus Paul Zmeskall, Hungarian cellist and composer, baptized in Leštiny (d. 1833)

János Batsányi, Hungarian poet (d. 1845)

János Lavotta, Hungarian violinist and composer, born in Pusté Úľany, Slovakia, Habsburg Empire (d. 1820)

Farkas Bolyai, Hungarian mathematician known for his work on the foundations of geometry and the parallel axiom (Wallace–Bolyai–Gerwien theorem), born in Bolya, Grand Principality of Transylvania (d. 1856)

János Fusz, Hungarian-German composer, born in Tolna, Hungary (d. 1819)

Alexander Csoma de Kőrös, Hungarian Tibetan scholar (first Tibetan-English Dictionary), born in Kőrös, Transylvania (d. 1842)

Karoly Kisfaludy, Hungarian pioneering dramatist (A Tat rok Magyarorsz gon), born in Tét, Hungary (d. 1830)

István Ferenczy, Hungarian sculptor (d. 1856)

Antonio Rosmini-Serbati, Italian philosopher and priest (founder Institute of Charity), born in Rovereto, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1855)

Gábor Mátray, Hungarian composer and musicologist, born in Nagykata, Hungary (d. 1875)

Ányos Jedlik, Hungarian physicist (d. 1895)

Gergely Czuczor, Hungarian-Czech poet and translator (Great Hung dictionary), born in Andód (d. 1866)

Nikolaus Lenau, Hungarian-German poet (Faust, Die Albigenser), born in Lenauheim, Banat, Romania (d. 1850)

Lajos Kossuth, Hungarian lawyer, politician, journalist, and liberal revolutionary (Governor-President of Hungary, 1849), born in Monok, Austria-Hungary (now Hungary)y (d. 1894)

Janos Bolyai, Hungarian mathematician (non-Euclidean geometry), born in Kolozsvár, Hungary (d. 1860)

Jozsef Bajza, Hungarian poet and critic, born in Szücsi (d. 1858)

Ludwig von Benedek, Hungarian born Austrian general (battle of Königgrätz), born in Sopron, Kingdom of Hungary Empire (d. 1881)

Györg Apponyi, Hungarian politician, born in Pozsony, Kingdom of Hungary (d. 1899)

Ferenc Erkel, Hungarian composer (Himnusz), born in Gyula (d. 1893)

Joseph Gungl, Austro-Hungarian bandleader and composer of dances and marches, born in Zsámbék, Hungary (d. 1889)

Franz Liszt, Hungarian romantic composer and virtuoso pianist (Faust Symphony), born in Raiding, Hungary (d. 1886)

Alexander Sandor Asboth, Hungarian-American Brevet Major General (Union Army), born in Keszthely, Hungary (d. 1868)

Heinrich Wilhelm Ernst, Moravian violinist and composer, born in Brno, Kingdom of Bohemia, Austro-Hungarian Empire 1865)

Stephen Heller, Hungarian composer and pianist, born in Pest (d. 1888)

Ede Szigligeti [József Szathmáry], Hungarian dramatist, born in Nagyvárad-Olaszi (d. 1878)

Béni Egressy, Hungarian composer, librettist, and actor, born in Kazincbarcika, Hungary (d. 1851)

Stefan Dunjov, Banat Bulgarian military figure involved in Hungarian revolution and Italian unification, born in Vinga, Hungary (d. 1889)

Mihály Mosonyi, Hungarian composer, born in Boldogasszony, Austria-Hungary (d. 1870)

Janos Arany, Hungarian epic poet (Toldi, Death of King Buda), born in Nagyszalonta, Kingdom of Hungary (d. 1882)

Károly Thern, Hungarian composer, born in Spišská Nová Ves, Slovakia (d. 1886)

Ignaz Semmelweis, Hungarian physician who discovered the cause of puerperal (childbed) fever and introduced antisepsis into medical practice, born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1865)

(Albert) Béla Kéler, Hungarian composer, and conductor, born in Bártfa, Kingdom of Hungary (now Bardejov, Slovakia) (d. 1882)

Sándor Petőfi, Hungarian poet (A virágnak megtiltani nem lehet - You Cannot Forbid the Flower), and revolutionary, born in Kiskőrös, Kingdom of Hungary, Austrian Empire (d. 1849)

Imre Madách, Hungarian writer (d. 1864)

Julius H [Szamvald] Stahel, Hungarian-American diplomat, mining engineer, and Major General (Union Army), born in Szeged, Hungary (d. 1912)

Eduard Reményi, Hungarian violinist and composer, born in Miskolc, Austria-Hungary (d. 1898) [some sources cite birth year as 1830]

(Károly) "Karl" Goldmark, Hungarian-Viennese violinist and composer (Rustic Wedding Symphony; The Queen of Sheba; Sakuhtala), born in Keszthely, Kingdom of Hungary (d. 1915)

Joseph Joachim, German violinist (Hungarian Concerto), born in Köpcsény, Moson County, Kingdom of Hungary (d. 1907)

Josef Foerster, Czech composer and music teacher, born in Osenice, Bohemia, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1907)

Johannes Brahms, German composer and conductor (Hungarian Dances; A German Requiem), born in Hamburg, German Confederation (d. 1897)

Gyula Beliczay, Hungarian pianist, composer, teacher, and engineer, born in Révkomárom, Hungary (now in Slovakia) (d. 1893)

Ádám Politzer, Hungarian-Austrian physician, born in Albertirsa, Pest, Hungary (d. 1920)

Gyula Erkel, Hungarian composer, son of Ferenc Erkel, born in Pest, Hungary (d. 1909)

Ödön Mihalovich, Hungarian composer, born in Fericsánci, Slavonia (d. 1929)

Hans Richter, Austrian-Hungarian composer, born in Raab, Kingdom of Hungary, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1916)

Jan Malát, Czech composer, pedagogue, and musicologist, born in Starý Bydžov, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1915)

Elek Erkel, Hungarian composer, son of Ferenc Erkel, born in Pest (d. 1893)

Josef Sucher, Hungarian composer and conductor (Aus alten Märchen), born in Döbör, Hungary (d. 1908)

József Kiss, Hungarian literary (Zsido Dalok), born in Mezőcsát, Hungary (d. 1921)

Leopold von Auer, Hungarian-American violinist, born in Veszprém, Hungary (d. 1930)

Sandor Erkel, Hungarian composer and son of Ferenc Erkel, born in Pest (d. 1900)

Albert Apponyi, Hungarian politician (Minister of Religion and Education of Hungary), born in Vienna, Austrian Empire (d. 1933)

Joseph Pulitzer, Hungarian-American publisher (St Louis Post-Dispatch, NY World) and Democratic politician whose bequest founded the Columbia School of Journalism and the Pulitzer Prize, born in Makó, Kingdom of Hungary (d. 1911)

Loránd Eötvös, Hungarian physicist (introduced idea of molecular surface tension), born in Buda, Hungary (d. 1919)

Géza Zichy, Hungarian composer and one-armed pianist, born at Sztára Castle, Hungary (d. 1924)

Fritz Mauthner, Austro-Hungarian novelist and critic, born in Hořice, Czech Republic (d. 1923)

Franz Graf Conrad von Hötzendorf, Austro-Hungarian field marshal, born in Penzing, Vienna, Austrian Empire (d. 1925)

Gyula Reviczky, Hungarian author and poet, born in Kuzmice, Topoľčany District, Slovakia (d. 1889)

Arthur Nikisch, Hungarian conductor (Berlin Philharmonic), born in Mosonszentmiklós, Hungary (d. 1922)

Svetozar Boroević, Austro-Hungarian field marshal, born in Umetić, Croatian Military Frontier, Austrian Empire (d. 1920)

Sylvio Lazzari, Austrian-French choir master and composer (La Lépreuse), born in Bolzano, South Tyrol, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1944)

Rudolf Franz Karl Joseph, Crown Prince of Austria and heir apparent to the Imperial throne of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, born in Schloss Laxenburg, Lower Austria, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1889)

Jenő Hubay [Huber], Hungarian violinist, composer, and educator (Budapest Conservatory, 1886-1934), born in Pest, Hungary (d. 1937)

Jakab Gyula Major, Hungarian pianist and composer, born in Kosice, Czech Republic (d. 1925)

Gyula Andrássy, Jr., Hungarian politician and Foreign Minister of Austria-Hungary (1918-20), born in Tőketerebes, Kingdom of Hungary, Austrian Empire (d. 1929)

Marc Aurel Stein, Hungarian-British archaeologist, born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1943)

Emánuel Moór, Hungarian composer, pianist, and inventor of musical instruments, born in Kecskemét, Hungary (d. 1931)

Árpád Szendy, Hungarian pianist, composer, and educator, born in Szarvas, Hungary (d. 1922)

Ion Vidu, Romanian composer and conductor, born in Mânerău, Arad district, Hungarian Kingdom (now Romainia) (d. 1931)

Emmuska Orczy, Hungarian-born British Baroness and writer (The Scarlet Pimpernel), born in Tarnaörs Hungary (d. 1947)

Ottokar Eugen Novacek, Hungarian composer and violinist of Czech descent, born in Weißkirchen, Austrian Empire (d. 1900)

Snitz Edwards [Edward Neumann], Hungarian-American stage and silent film actor ("Phantom of the Opera"; "College"), born in Budapest, Austria-Hungary (d. 1937)

Cyril Metodej Hrazdira, Czech composer and conductor, born in Rájec nad Svitavou, Moravia, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1926)

Paolo Gallico, Italian-American concert pianist, composer (The Apocalypse), and educator, born in Trieste, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1955)

Miklós Horthy, Hungarian navy admiral, military leader, anti-communist statesman (Regent of Kingdom of Hungary, 1920-44), and Nazi abettor, born in Kenderes, Austria-Hungary (d. 1957)

Aleš Hrdlička, Austro-Hungarian anthropologist and curator (US National Museum), born in Humpolec, Austria-Hungary (d. 1943)

Ede Poldini, Hungarian composer (La poupée valsante; The Vagabond and the Princess), born in Pest, Hungary (d. 1957)

Franz Lehár, Austrian-Hungarian composer (Naughty Marietta), born in Komárom, Austria-Hungary (d. 1948)

Fran Saleški Finžgar, Slovene folk writer (Our Blood, Service Girls), born in Doslovče, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1962)

Vojtěch Říhovský, Czech composer, born in Dub nad Moravou, Bohemia, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1950)

Akos Buttykai, Hungarian composer, born in Halmeu, Romania (d. 1935)

Prince Friedrich Aloys Johannes Maria, Prince of Liechtenstein, born in Arad, Hungarian Kingdom (now Romania) (d. 1959)

Ottokar Czernin, Austro-Hungarian diplomat (Imperial Foreign Minister of Austria-Hungary) and politician, born in Dimokur, Austria-Hungary (d. 1932)

Adolph Zukor, Hungarian-American movie producer, director and executive (Paramount), born in Ricse, Hungary (d. 1976)

Leo Fall, Austrian operetta composer (Dollar Princess), born in Olmütz, Austrian-Hungarian Empire (d. 1925)

Ferenc Szisz, Hungarian auto racer (winner 1st Grand Prix motor racing event in Le Mans, France 1906), born in Szeghalom, Hungary (d. 1944)

Carl Flesch, Hungarian violinist, born in Mosonmagyaróvár, Hungary (d. 1944)

Kacsóh Pongrác, Hungarian composer, born in Budapest, Austria-Hungary (d. 1923)

Kincsem, Hungarian horse that never lost a race, born in Kisbér, Hungary (d. 1877)

Karl Kraus, Austrian satirical writer, born in Jičín, Austrian-Hungarian Empire (d. 1936)

Jenő Huszka, Hungarian composer (Bob herceg (Prince Bob)), born in Szeged, Hungary (d. 1960)

Ferdinand Porsche, German automotive engineer (Volkswagen Beetle, Mercedes-Benz SS) and founder of the Porsche car company, born in Maffersdorf, Bohemia, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1951)

Józef Hofmann, Polish-American pianist, composer, educator (Curtis Institute, 1924-38), and inventor, born in Podgórze, Austro-Hungarian Galicia (now Poland) (d. 1957)

Béla Schick, Hungarian-American paediatrician (Schick test), born in Balatonboglár, Hungary (d. 1967)

Ernst von Dohnányi [Dohnányi Ernő], Hungarian composer and conductor, born in Pozsony, Kingdom of Hungary, Austria-Hungary (d. 1960)

Endre Ady, Hungarian lyric poet (Még egyzer, Uj versek), born in Ermindszent, Hungary (d. 1919)

Ferenc Molnar, Hungarian American playwright (A Pal Utrai Fiuk) and novelist (The Paul Street Boys), born in Budapest, Austria-Hungary (d. 1952)

Alfréd Hajós, Hungarian swimmer (Olympic gold 100/200m 1896), soccer forward (1 cap) and manager (Hungary 1906), born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1955)

Albert Siklós, Hungarian composer, born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1942)

William Fox [Wilhem Fuchs], Hungarian-American movie theater pioneer and film producer (Fox Film Corporation), born in Tolcsva, Kingdom of Hungary (d. 1952)

Dezső Lauber, Hungarian competitive athlete (Ice skating, golf, tennis, cycling), and architect, born in Pecs, Hungary (d. 1966)

Oskar Back, Hungarian-Dutch violist and pedagogue, born in Vienna, Austria (d. 1963)

Eugen Varga, Hungarian-Russian economist and politician, born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1964)

Paul Ehrenfest, Austrian-Dutch theoretical physicist (phase transition, Ehrenfest theorem), born in Vienna, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1933)

Lipót Fejér, Hungarian mathematician (d. 1959)

Frigyes Riesz, Hungarian mathematician (d. 1956)

Margit Kaffka, Hungarian writer (Colors and Years), born in Nagykároly (d. 1918)

Albert Szirmai, Hungarian operetta composer, born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1967)

Béla Bartók, Hungarian pianist, composer (Concerto for Orchestra), and ethnomusicologist, born in Nagyszentmiklós, Kingdom of Hungary, Austria-Hungary (d. 1945)

Theodore von Kármán, Hungarian-born American physicist and aeronautic engineer (co-founder NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory), born in Budapest, Austria-Hungary (d. 1963)

Ilona Durigo, Hungarian contralto singer, born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1943)

Sándor Graf Festetics, Hungarian nobleman and politician (Minister of War, 1918-19), born in Dég, Fejér county, Hungary (d. 1956)

Riccardo Pick-Mangiagalli, Italian composer, born in Strakonice, Kingdom of Bohemia, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1949)

Emil Ábrányi, Hungarian composer, conductor, and opera director, born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1970)

Bela Lugosi [Blaskó], Austrian actor (Dracula, Plan 9 From Outer Space), born in Lugos, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1956)

Emmerich Kálmán, Hungarian composer of operettas, born in Siófok, Austria-Hungary (d. 1953)

Otto Neurath, Austrian-British philosopher (Foundation of Social Sciences), born in Vienna, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1945)

Zoltán Kodály, Hungarian composer and ethnomusicologist, (Psalmus Hungaricus; Hary Janos), born in Kecskemét, Hungary (d. 1967)

S Z Sakall [Gerö Jenö], Hungarian stage and film character actor (Dolly Sisters, Casablanca), born in Budapest Hungary (d. 1955)

Zoltán Meskó, Hungarian Nazi (d. 1959)

Viktor Jacobi, Hungarian operetta composer (Szibill), born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1921)

Edward Kilenyi, Sr. [Kilényi Ede], Hungarian composer and teacher (Clipped Wings, Outside the Law), born in Békésszentandrás, Hungary (d. 1968)

Petru Groza, Austro-Hungarian born Romanian communist and President of Romania (1945-58), born in Băcia, Austria-Hungary (d. 1958)

Georg Lukács, Hungarian philosopher and literary critic, born in Budapest, Austria-Hungary (d. 1971)

Leo Weiner, Hungarian composer (Fasching), born in Budapest, Austria-Hungary (d. 1960)

Artúr Harmat, Hungarian composer, born in Bojná, Hungary (d. 1962)

Desider Antalffy-Zsiross, Hungarian organist and composer, born in Nagybecskerek, Hungary (d. 1945)

George de Hevesy, Hungarian radiochemist (Nobel Prize in Chemistry -1943), born in Budapest, Austria-Hungary (d. 1966)

Alfred Haar, Hungarian mathematician, born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1933)

János Hammerschlag, Hungarian composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1954)

Bela Kun, Hungarian Communist revolutionary (de facto head of Hungarian Soviet Republic 1919), born in Lele, Hungary (d. 1938)

Karl Polanyi, Austro-Hungarian economic anthropologist (The Great Transformation), born in Vienna, Austria-Hungary (d. 1964)

Michael Curtiz, Hungarian-born American film director, born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1962)

Nandor Zsolt, Hungarian composer, born in Esztergom, Hungary (d. 1936)

Sigmund Romberg, Hungarian-American operetta composer (Blossom Time), born in Nagykanizsa, Austria-Hungary (d. 1951)

Bernhard Paumgartner, Austrian musicologist, conductor, and composer, born in Vienna, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1971)

George Pólya, Hungarian mathematician, born in Budapest, Austria-Hungary (d. 1985)

Joseph Csaky, Hungarian-French sculptor (Cubism), born in Szeged, Austria-Hungary (d. 1971)

(Frederick) "Fritz" Reiner, Hungarian-American conductor (Cincinnati Symphony, 1922-31; Pittsburgh Symphony, 1938-48; Chicago Symphony Orchestra, 1953-63), and educator (Curtis Institute), born in Budapest, Austria-Hungary (d. 1963)

Gabriel von Wayditch, Hungarian-American composer, born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1969)

Lajos Asztalos, Hungarian chess player (International Chess Master 1950), born in Pécs, Hungary (d. 1956)

Sandor Rado, Hungarian-American psychoanalyst, born in Kisvárda, Hungary (d. 1972)

Karl Freund, German cinematographer and film director (Dracula; I Love Lucy; The Mummy), born in Dvůr Králové (Königinhof), Bohemia, Austria-Hungarian Empire (d. 1969)

Egon Schiele, Austrian painter and graphic artist, born in Tulln an der Donau, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1918)

Sándor Jemnitz, Hungarian composer, born in Budapest, Kingdom of Hungary, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1963)

Lily Kronberger, Hungarian figure skater (d. 1974)

Franz Alexander, Hungarian-American psychoanalyst (pioneered psychosomatic medicine), born in Budapest, Austria-Hungary (d. 1964)

Michael Polanyi, Hungarian-English chemist, economist and philosopher (claimed all knowledge relied on personal judgments), born in Budapest, Austria-Hungary (d. 1976)

Victor Varconi, Hungarian actor (Divine Lady; King of Kings; Big City), born in Kisvárda, Austria-Hungary (d. 1976)

František Suchý, Czech composer and folk song collector, born in Březové Hory, Bohemia, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1973)

Egon Kornauth, Austrian composer, born in Olmütz, Kingdom of Moravia, Austria-Hungarian (d. 1959)

István Kardos, Hungarian composer, born in Debrecen, Hungary (d. 1975)

Tin Ujević, Croatian poet (Žedan kamen na studencu), born in Vrgorac, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1955)

János Viski, Hungarian painter best known for his works of galloping horses, born in Szokolya, Hungary (d. 1987)

Miklós Radnai, Hungarian composer (Symphony of the Magyars), music writer, and critic, born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1935)

Mátyás Rákosi, Hungarian party leader and Prime Minister (1952-53), born in Ada, Serbia (d. 1971)

Jozsef Mindszenty [József Pehm], Hungarian cardinal who opposed fascism and communism in Hungary, born in Csehimindszent, Hungary (d. 1975)

Jaroslav Kvapil, Czech composer, born in Fryšták, Bohemia, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1959)

Edward Steuermann, Austrian-American pianist and composer, born in Sambor, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1964)

László Lajtha, Hungarian composer, ethnomusicologist and conductor, born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1963)

Joseph Szigeti, Hungarian violinist (Violinist Notebook 1933), born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1973)

Paul Abraham, Hungarian composer (Viktoria und ihr Huzar), born in Apatin, Austria-Hungary (d. 1960)

Zoltán Böszörmény, Hungarian Nazi politician, born in Budapest, Hungary (d. unknown)

Cornelius Lanczos, Hungarian mathematician, born in Székesfehérvár, Hungary (d. 1974)

Karl Mannheim, Hungarian sociologist and writer (Ideology and Utopia; Diagnosis of Our Time), born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1947)

Albert Szent-Györgyi, Hungarian biochemist (Vitamin C, Nobel 1937), born in Budapest, Austria-Hungary (d. 1986)

[Johann Baptist] Hanns Albin Rauter, German SS and Police leader in the occupied Netherlands, born in Klagenfurt, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1949)

Fidél Pálffy, Hungarian National socialist (leading supporter of Nazism in Hungary), born in Szentgyörgy, Austria-Hungary (d. 1946)

Paul Lukas, Hungarian actor (Watch on the Rhine, Sphynx), born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1971)

Zoltan Korda, Hungarian-British film director (Jungle Book, 4 Feathers), born in Pusztatúrpásztó, Austria-Hungary (d. 1961)

László Moholy-Nagy, Hungarian painter, photographer, and sculptor, born in Borsód, Austria-Hungary (d. 1946)

Imre Nagy, Hungarian communist and Prime Minister of Hungary (1953-56), born in Kaposvár, Hungary (d. 1958)

Tadeusz Szeligowski, Polish composer (The Peacock and the Girl), born in Lemberg, Austro-Hungarian Galicia (now Lviv, Ukraine) (d. 1963)

Jolie Gabor [Janka Tilleman], Hungarian-American jeweler and mother of Magda, Zsa Zsa, & Eva, born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1997) [birth date disputed]

György Kósa, Hungarian composer, born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1984)

Kálmán Tihanyi, Hungarian physicist and engineer (invented cathode ray tube for television), born in Üzbég, Kingdom of Hungary (d. 1947)

George Szell, Hungarian-born American conductor (Cleveland Orchestra, 1946-70), born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1970)

Elmar Berkovich, Hungarian-Dutch industrial designer (Eindhoven Theatre), born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1967)

Leó Szilárd, Hungarian-German-American nuclear physicist (Manhattan Project) and peace activist, born in Budapest, Hungary, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1964)

Tibor Harsányi, Hungarian pianist, composer, and conductor who settled Paris, France, born in Magyarkanizsa, Kingdom of Hungary (d. 1954)

Oscar Homolka, Hungarian actor (Sabotage, The Seven Year Itch, Ball of Fire, I Remember Mama), born in Vienna, Austria-Hungary (d. 1978)

Béla Guttmann, Hungarian soccer midfielder (4 caps; MTK Hungária, Hakoah Wien) and coach (Benfica, AC Milan, FC Porto; Hungary, Austria, Netherlands, Italy, Brazil, Uruguay, Portugal), born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1981)

Bella Spewack, Hungarian-American playwright (Kiss Me Kate), born in Bucharest, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1990)

Georg von Bekesy, Hungarian-American physician and physiologist (Nobel Prize in Physioloy or Medicine 1961 for work on the inner ear), born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1972)

Brassaï [Gyula Halász], Hungarian-French artist, born in Brassó, Austria-Hungary (d. 1984)

Lásló Jósef Bíró, Hungarian inventor (ballpoint pen), born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1985)

Lajos Bárdos, Hungarian conductor, composer, musicologist and professor, born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1986)

Eugene Ormandy [Jenő Blau], Hungarian-American violinist and conductor (Philadelphia Orchestra, 1936-80), born in Budapest (d. 1985)

Hermann Kesten, German writer (Allert de Lange), born in Pidvolochysk, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1996)

Zoltán Vásárhelyi, Hungarian violinist, teacher, and choral conductor, born in Kecskemét, Hungary (d. 1977)

Sándor Márai, Hungarian writer (A gyertyák csonkig égnek), born in Kassa, Hungary (d. 1989)
